[{'created': '2019-05-27 11:42:11.000000000', 'message': 'Fix run-os-net-config.sh to use ping6 for IPv6 hostnames

The run-os-net-config.sh script checks to see if an IP address is
IPv4 or IPv6, and uses ping or ping6 accordingly. This change also
resolves hostnames and submits the resolved IP to the same test.
If the hostname only resolves to an IPv6 address, then ping6 will
be used.

Change-Id: I9f37992157935b37cc9beb8a2f3b9d749a62bd1b
Closes-bug: 1830274
(cherry picked from commit 68bfc267286a9523f89a73718a7ed11cdc787a96)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix run-os-net-config.sh to use ping6 for IPv6 hostnames

The run-os-net-config.sh script checks to see if an IP address is
IPv4 or IPv6, and uses ping or ping6 accordingly. This change also
resolves hostnames and submits the resolved IP to the same test.
If the hostname only resolves to an IPv6 address, then ping6 will
be used.

Change-Id: I9f37992157935b37cc9beb8a2f3b9d749a62bd1b
Closes-bug: 1830274
(cherry picked from commit 68bfc267286a9523f89a73718a7ed11cdc787a96)

commit_message:
Adds tox docs job

Follow PTI for this and add all needed changes, remove obsolete
options. Switch to openstackdocstheme instead of oslosphinx
since that is retired.

Remove module index - this repo has no modules and thus nothing is
generated.

Add job to publish documents.

Change-Id: Ida269f9755099f32a12f46082b529311ecb7e2b6

subject: OpenDev Migration Patch
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-28 01:56:59.000000000', 'message': "OpenDev Migration Patch

This commit was bulk generated and pushed by the OpenDev sysadmins
as a part of the Git hosting and code review systems migration
detailed in these mailing list posts:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003603.html
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004920.html

Attempts have been made to correct repository namespaces and
hostnames based on simple pattern matching, but it's possible some
were updated incorrectly or missed entirely. Please reach out to us
via the contact information listed at https://opendev.org/ with any
questions you may have.

Change-Id: Ic104ead401f8bff75a32cf6e5f2def5cdce51629
"}]
commit_message:
OpenDev Migration Patch

This commit was bulk generated and pushed by the OpenDev sysadmins
as a part of the Git hosting and code review systems migration
detailed in these mailing list posts:

http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-March/003603.html
http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-April/004920.html

Attempts have been made to correct repository namespaces and
hostnames based on simple pattern matching, but it's possible some
were updated incorrectly or missed entirely. Please reach out to us
via the contact information listed at https://opendev.org/ with any
questions you may have.

Change-Id: Ic104ead401f8bff75a32cf6e5f2def5cdce51629

commit_message:
allow building docs without ceilometer client

CeilometerClient has been deprecated and is no longer available for
master. Without ceilometer client installed docs fail to build with
an exception [1].

This patch marks the import optional.

commit_message:
Add case for router east west traffic

In order to avoid unexpected regression, this patch adds one
test case for router east west traffic.

Change-Id: I695e833ccedddafaf9f5b7ccbd4831f02efde733

commit_message:
Show all SG rules belong to SG in group's details

If security group contains rule(s) which were created by different
user (admin), owner of this security group should see such rules
even if those rules don't belong to him.

This patch changes to use admin_context to get security group rules
in get_security_group() method to achieve that.

Test to cover such case is added in neutron-tempest-plugin repo.

Change-Id: I890c81bb6eabc5caa620ed4fcc4dc88ebfa6e1b0
Closes-Bug: #1824248
(cherry picked from commit 1920a37a94b7a9589dcf83f6ff0765068560dbf8)

commit_message:
Normalize url without port with schema default port

In function get_bare_url, it will assert url startswith base_url,
if base_url is 'http://neutron.openstack.svc.cluster.local:80/',
while url is 'http://neutron.openstack.svc.cluster.local/v2.0/router/...',
it will raise error. here need to add default schema port 80 to url to
fix this problem.

Change-Id: I44d623d3d0d96711f7ca93fc24b40c024dd86446
Closes-Bug: #1829962

commit_message:
fix releasenotes testenv.

The release of 4.0.0 failed due to:

 $ tox -re releasenotes
 releasenotes create: /home/tony/projects/OSF/openstack/tripleo-upgrade/.tox/releasenotes
 releasenotes installdeps: -r/home/tony/projects/OSF/openstack/tripleo-upgrade/test-requirements.txt
 releasenotes develop-inst: /home/tony/projects/OSF/openstack/tripleo-upgrade
 releasenotes installed: aspy.yaml==1.3.0,Babel==2.6.0,bashate==0.6.0,cached-property==1.5.1,cfgv==1.6.0,flake8==2.5.5,hacking==0.12.0,identify==1.4.3,importlib-metadata==0.13,mccabe==0.2.1,nodeenv==1.3.3,pbr==5.2.
 0,pep8==1.5.7,pre-commit==1.13.0,pyflakes==0.8.1,pytz==2019.1,PyYAML==5.1,six==1.12.0,toml==0.10.0,-e git+https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-upgrade@39d4b47821829edbd0ad7d393262b60324f815a4#egg=tripleo_upgrade,
 virtualenv==16.6.0,zipp==0.5.1
 releasenotes run-test-pre: PYTHONHASHSEED='2527801070'
 releasenotes runtests: commands[0] | bash -c ci-scripts/releasenotes_tox.sh
 Running Sphinx v1.7.6

 Extension error:
 Could not import extension openstackdocstheme (exception: No module named 'openstackdocstheme')
 ERROR: InvocationError for command '/usr/bin/bash -c ci-scripts/releasenotes_tox.sh' (exited with code 2)

Fix that my adding openstackdocstheme, sphinx and reno to
test-requirements.

Another solution would be to follow the PTI and have a specific
doc/requirements.txt but that's a bigger change and probably not
justified currently

Change-Id: I96bfe4f141a587eec1d55b37a60f6b58a6009265

(cherry picked from commit 68bfc267286a9523f89a73718a7ed11cdc787a96)
'}]
commit_message:
Fix run-os-net-config.sh to use ping6 for IPv6 hostnames

The run-os-net-config.sh script checks to see if an IP address is
IPv4 or IPv6, and uses ping or ping6 accordingly. This change also
resolves hostnames and submits the resolved IP to the same test.
If the hostname only resolves to an IPv6 address, then ping6 will
be used.

Change-Id: I9f37992157935b37cc9beb8a2f3b9d749a62bd1b
Closes-bug: 1830274
(cherry picked from commit 68bfc267286a9523f89a73718a7ed11cdc787a96)

commit_message:
Use stable ARA setup interface for defining the callback location

ARA ships simple setup modules to help figure out the paths
to where things are located.
These are backwards compatible from ARA 1.0 to 0.x.

Change-Id: Ie29caf04bb9ab007a9c42b72bb68a3a3a861c749
(cherry picked from commit 40e26e69cee9e42183d8e88c3b3cc177e7966b1a)

(3 comments)

Hey Jerry, TBO I am not clear about the doc improvement you are trying to achieve.

Why would we need to setup dhcp provider explicitly? It's "neutron" by default, in such case, neutron dhcp agent will provide dhcp services, I think it's already covered by the existing doc: https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/install/configure-networking.html

We only need to setup a dhcp service when ironic is running in standalone: https://docs.openstack.org/ironic/latest/install/standalone.html

Maybe you can check if there is something which you considered is lacking there?'}, {'account_id': 29792, 'date': '2019-04-06 13:14:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 29792, 'date': '2019-04-06 13:33:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-20 10:38:04.000000000', 'message': 'Clarify supported SUSE versions

This role only support openSUSE Leap 15, not 42.3, not tumbleweed.
Saying all is confusing and a bad practice. This fixes it, while
ensuring the job is properly defined to test that assertion.

Change-Id: I8d4bccbe283a0b09f42e2d2419612b3a4a1c6a0d
'}, {'created': '2019-05-27 07:15:23.000000000', 'message': 'Clarify supported SUSE versions

This role only support openSUSE Leap 15, not 42.3, not tumbleweed.
Saying all is confusing and a bad practice. This fixes it, while
ensuring the job is properly defined to test that assertion.

Change-Id: I8d4bccbe283a0b09f42e2d2419612b3a4a1c6a0d
'}]
commit_message:
Clarify supported SUSE versions

This role only support openSUSE Leap 15, not 42.3, not tumbleweed.
Saying all is confusing and a bad practice. This fixes it, while
ensuring the job is properly defined to test that assertion.

Change-Id: I8d4bccbe283a0b09f42e2d2419612b3a4a1c6a0d

commit_message:
functional: Adopt WaitEvent in metadata agent tests

Since ovsdbapp 0.14.0 release, there is a WaitEvent class. This patch
adopts it.

Change-Id: Ib2da7738b817185bcbc58a992da28ce29a8e07d2

commit_message:
Add user messages for some volume snapshot actions

Also adds tests to help keep the message_field module
consistent.

Co-authored-by: TommyLike <tommylikehu@gmail.com>
Co-authored-by: Brian Rosmaita <rosmaita.fossdev@gmail.com>

Change-Id: I8a16c9742cadfee1a75a6d738945476a9fc7c19b

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-26 21:13:59.000000000', 'message': "Correct os-cinder-install task serialisation

The code should run two batches, a single host followed by all
remaining hosts by passing a list ['1', '100%'] as the serial
parameter. The list was not initialised correctly.

Change-Id: I99b5e9bd088af3633a4f186af6d2081c632ccf4f
"}]
commit_message:
Correct os-cinder-install task serialisation

The code should run two batches, a single host followed by all
remaining hosts by passing a list ['1', '100%'] as the serial
parameter. The list was not initialised correctly.

Change-Id: I99b5e9bd088af3633a4f186af6d2081c632ccf4f

commit_message:
devstack: configure rabbit outside of API configuration

If enabled, rabbit is required for all ironic services, so it makes
no sense to only configure it when API is enabled. This seems to
break multinode grenade, since `is_service_enabled ir-api` returns
false on the subnode. Try to configure the RPC backend in all cases
when IRONIC_RPC_TRANSPORT is "oslo" (not JSON RPC).

Also move the automated_clean option to the conductor where it belongs.

Change-Id: I6e046c6b6e1e4c0ca7bfd5fb9ce5892c0298fb78

[{'created': '2019-05-21 06:45:16.000000000', 'message': 'Do not set port addresses on LSP while port not bound

FIP that points to VIP port could not have addresses
specified [1]. Router pipeline will try to resolve
ARP requests internally from LSP instead looking for
actual MAC address from LSP where VIP exists at this moment.

Lets not set this address till the port is bound.

[1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1707241

Change-Id: I36261701be393584ad4b00ced96273736339b03c
Closes-Bug: #1789686
(cherry picked from commit 33fd553158a96b4dc40c66acf050fa7f91227dec)
'}]
commit_message:
Do not set port addresses on LSP while port not bound

FIP that points to VIP port could not have addresses
specified [1]. Router pipeline will try to resolve
ARP requests internally from LSP instead looking for
actual MAC address from LSP where VIP exists at this moment.

Lets not set this address till the port is bound.

[1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1707241

Change-Id: I36261701be393584ad4b00ced96273736339b03c
Closes-Bug: #1789686
(cherry picked from commit 33fd553158a96b4dc40c66acf050fa7f91227dec)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-15 02:50:59.000000000', 'message': 'Skip _exclude_nested_providers() if not nested

In rocky cycle, 'GET /allocation_candidates' started to be aware of
nested providers from microversion 1.29, namely, it can have multiple
allocations from multiple resource providers in the same tree in the
allocation requests.

To keep the behavior of microversion before 1.29, it added a filters
to exculde nested providers being unaware of the nested architecture.
However that function "_exclude_nested_providers()" is very heavy
and is executed even if there is no nested provider in the environment
when microversion < 1.29.

This patch changes it to skip it if there is no nested provider.

Since _exclude_nested_providers() should be done before limitting
the candidates, this patch also moves it from hander file to the
deeper layer.

This is manually backported from the placement repository:
commit 727fb88dccfe8461cc40ae53ca2d4e40fd2a9c3c

Change-Id: I4efdc65395e69a6d33fba927018d003cce26fa68
Closes-Bug: #1828937

(cherry picked from commit 3b17dd7615ab85b751fc875f2391fcc2c34eeee6)
'}]
commit_message:
Skip _exclude_nested_providers() if not nested

In rocky cycle, 'GET /allocation_candidates' started to be aware of
nested providers from microversion 1.29, namely, it can have multiple
allocations from multiple resource providers in the same tree in the
allocation requests.

To keep the behavior of microversion before 1.29, it added a filters
to exculde nested providers being unaware of the nested architecture.
However that function "_exclude_nested_providers()" is very heavy
and is executed even if there is no nested provider in the environment
when microversion < 1.29.

This patch changes it to skip it if there is no nested provider.

Since _exclude_nested_providers() should be done before limitting
the candidates, this patch also moves it from hander file to the
deeper layer.

This is manually backported from the placement repository:
commit 727fb88dccfe8461cc40ae53ca2d4e40fd2a9c3c

Change-Id: I4efdc65395e69a6d33fba927018d003cce26fa68
Closes-Bug: #1828937
(cherry picked from commit 3b17dd7615ab85b751fc875f2391fcc2c34eeee6)

commit_message:
Change [nova_client]/api_version default to service_default

With [1] current default '2' for [nova_client]/api_version
no longer works, it needs version to be in format X.Y,
let's use watcher service default which is 2.56 currently.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/659194/
Change-Id: Ieea49092c5f323686844161361a6e5e24e4971f6

[{'created': '2019-04-25 10:01:27.000000000', 'message': "Fix download upper constraints

We use the url from tox.ini to download the upper constraints and
recently that has changed to a redirect and curl doesn't
correctly follows redirects by default but stops at the first
page.
Adding -L option to curl command makes curl follows the redirect
until the final location is found and should allow the correct
file to be downloaded.

Change-Id: I25c724ffe189d414643c910be0ef61c550f802b7
(cherry picked from commit a88e61959bc41a10de5f58f8a1ffc34ae6f1e822)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix download upper constraints

We use the url from tox.ini to download the upper constraints and
recently that has changed to a redirect and curl doesn't
correctly follows redirects by default but stops at the first
page.
Adding -L option to curl command makes curl follows the redirect
until the final location is found and should allow the correct
file to be downloaded.

Change-Id: I25c724ffe189d414643c910be0ef61c550f802b7
(cherry picked from commit a88e61959bc41a10de5f58f8a1ffc34ae6f1e822)

commit_message:
Add ODL deprecation warning in CLI

ODL is deprecated since Rocky. Add a warning
before deployment asking the user if he wants
to continue with deployment even after
deprecation.

The logic is to check for neutron-opendaylight.yaml
environment file passed to overcloud deploy command.
If yes, ask for user confirmation before starting
deployment.

Change-Id: I1b16aab11591fac610cd4bf49a0927f1ec947146
Closes-Bug: #1827366
(cherry picked from commit 1fee54b9be6e877040a7d62183d72a35948767e0)

commit_message:
update "DROPDOWN_MAX_ITEMS" horizon parameter as a variable

"DROPDOWN_MAX_ITEMS" horizon parameter was hardcoded in a ruby
template. Hence, it was not possible to manage it using heat.
This fix will allow user to manage "DROPDOWN_MAX_ITEMS" from
heat template.

Change-Id: I121a4ad2070cfef173c572a3d25788abbbf16989
Closes-Bug: #1813786

[{'created': '2019-05-24 15:52:32.000000000', 'message': "Add table styling

Sphinx 2.0 switches the default HTML build from HTML4 to HTML5. HTML5
deprecates the 'border' attribute for the 'table' element and the HTML5
builder no longer emits this. This has resulted in a lack of borders on
tables.

Correct this by configuring border styling via CSS and then go a few
steps further and start colouring the table header and using zebra
stripes on rows to help visually distinguish them further. A sample
table is added to the demo documentation so we've something to inspect
locally.

commit_message:
Add table styling

Sphinx 2.0 switches the default HTML build from HTML4 to HTML5. HTML5
deprecates the 'border' attribute for the 'table' element and the HTML5
builder no longer emits this. This has resulted in a lack of borders on
tables.

Correct this by configuring border styling via CSS and then go a few
steps further and start colouring the table header and using zebra
stripes on rows to help visually distinguish them further. A sample
table is added to the demo documentation so we've something to inspect
locally.

Change-Id: I79b40bb5700807ac8ad523a6e0a83cd21965346e
Signed-off-by: Stephen Finucane <sfinucan@redhat.com>
Closes-Bug: #1828265

subject: ADD "SVM" CPU trait to amd.py
messages:
[{'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-04-29 09:35:31.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-04-29 14:49:14.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 6962, 'date': '2019-05-27 15:46:16.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

In favor of: 

https://review.opendev.org/655193'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-29 09:35:31.000000000', 'message': '[Request for Comments] ADD "SVM" CPU trait to amd.py

Context: We currently have two modules related to CPU traits:

 - amd.py: This has a single trait, "SEV", which is the AMD-specific CPU
   flag.

 - x86.py: This file can "imply" that it is Intel-only (otherwise, why
   would you have an "amd.py" file?  I realize that although the term
   "x86" is Intel-based, it can also apply to AMD and other vendors who
   hold an x86 architecture license).  So, as expected, the "x86.py"
   file has mostly Intel-specific CPU traits, but ... unexpectedly, it
   also has _one_ AMD-specific trait: "SVM" (Secure Virtual Machine).

The 'os_traits' water is now muddy.

So, as it stands, the "SVM" trait's module path is:

    os_traits.HW_CPU_X86_SVM

But if we _move_ it to x86.py, its module path becomes:

    os_traits.HW_CPU_AMD_SVM

However, we can't do that -- because as per `os-traits` "lifecycle
policy"[1] `os_traits.HW_CPU_X86_SVM` cannot ever go away, because it
will cause breakage.

Given all this, I _think_ we want to consolidate all AMD-related traits
into a single file, amd.py, and all Intel-related ones into x86.py.  (And
if a CPU trait is common between Intel and AMD, then they need to be
added to both amd.py and x86.py -- yes, this is repetitive, but maybe we
can live with it, unless we try Eric Fried's suggestion[2].

For now, add a note in x86.py saying that "SVM" is erroneously sitting
there.  And create a new trait in amd.py for "SVM".

            * * *

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/os-traits/latest/contributor/index.html

[2] To try _three_ modules:

      hw/cpu/x86.py (common to both Intel and AMD)
      hw/cpu/x86/amd.py (AMD-specific)
      hw/cpu/x86/intel.py (Intel-specific)

    And Jay Pipes seem to prefer "simplicity" and go with just "two
    files" approach.  If there's consensus on an approach brings
    clarity, consistency and "future-proofness", I'm all up for it.

Change-Id: I03a4c0fea621efa5efdd9bb8bfef3acfcfaee6fb
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>
'}, {'created': '2019-04-29 14:49:14.000000000', 'message': 'ADD "SVM" CPU trait to amd.py

Context: We currently have two modules related to CPU traits:

 - amd.py: This has a single trait, "SEV", which is the AMD-specific CPU
   flag.

 - x86.py: This file can "imply" that it is Intel-only (otherwise, why
   would you have an "amd.py" file?  I realize that although the term
   "x86" is Intel-based, it can also apply to AMD and other vendors who
   hold an x86 architecture license).  So, as expected, the "x86.py"
   file has mostly Intel-specific CPU traits, but ... unexpectedly, it
   also has _one_ AMD-specific trait: "SVM" (Secure Virtual Machine).

The 'os_traits' water is now muddy.

So, as it stands, the "SVM" trait's module path is:

    os_traits.HW_CPU_X86_SVM

But if we _move_ it to x86.py, its module path becomes:

    os_traits.HW_CPU_AMD_SVM

However, we can't do that -- because as per `os-traits` "lifecycle
policy"[1] `os_traits.HW_CPU_X86_SVM` cannot ever go away, because it
will cause breakage.

Given all this, I _think_ we want to consolidate all AMD-related traits
into a single file, amd.py, and all Intel-related ones into x86.py.  (And
if a CPU trait is common between Intel and AMD, then they need to be
added to both amd.py and x86.py -- yes, this is repetitive, but maybe we
can live with it, unless we try Eric Fried's suggestion[2].

For now, add a note in x86.py saying that "SVM" is erroneously sitting
there.  And create a new trait in amd.py for "SVM".

            * * *

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/os-traits/latest/contributor/index.html

[2] To try _three_ modules:

      hw/cpu/x86.py (common to both Intel and AMD)
      hw/cpu/x86/amd.py (AMD-specific)
      hw/cpu/x86/intel.py (Intel-specific)

    And Jay Pipes seem to prefer "simplicity" and go with just "two
    files" approach.  If there's consensus on an approach brings
    clarity, consistency and "future-proofness", I'm all up for it.

Change-Id: I03a4c0fea621efa5efdd9bb8bfef3acfcfaee6fb
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>
'}]
commit_message:
ADD "SVM" CPU trait to amd.py

Context: We currently have two modules related to CPU traits:

 - amd.py: This has a single trait, "SEV", which is the AMD-specific CPU
   flag.

 - x86.py: This file can "imply" that it is Intel-only (otherwise, why
   would you have an "amd.py" file?  I realize that although the term
   "x86" is Intel-based, it can also apply to AMD and other vendors who
   hold an x86 architecture license).  So, as expected, the "x86.py"
   file has mostly Intel-specific CPU traits, but ... unexpectedly, it
   also has _one_ AMD-specific trait: "SVM" (Secure Virtual Machine).

The 'os_traits' water is now muddy.

So, as it stands, the "SVM" trait's module path is:

    os_traits.HW_CPU_X86_SVM

But if we _move_ it to x86.py, its module path becomes:

    os_traits.HW_CPU_AMD_SVM

However, we can't do that -- because as per `os-traits` "lifecycle
policy"[1] `os_traits.HW_CPU_X86_SVM` cannot ever go away, because it
will cause breakage.

Given all this, I _think_ we want to consolidate all AMD-related traits
into a single file, amd.py, and all Intel-related ones into x86.py.  (And
if a CPU trait is common between Intel and AMD, then they need to be
added to both amd.py and x86.py -- yes, this is repetitive, but maybe we
can live with it, unless we try Eric Fried's suggestion[2].

For now, add a note in x86.py saying that "SVM" is erroneously sitting
there.  And create a new trait in amd.py for "SVM".

            * * *

[1] https://docs.openstack.org/os-traits/latest/contributor/index.html

[2] To try _three_ modules:

      hw/cpu/x86.py (common to both Intel and AMD)
      hw/cpu/x86/amd.py (AMD-specific)
      hw/cpu/x86/intel.py (Intel-specific)

    And Jay Pipes seem to prefer "simplicity" and go with just "two
    files" approach.  If there's consensus on an approach brings
    clarity, consistency and "future-proofness", I'm all up for it.

Change-Id: I03a4c0fea621efa5efdd9bb8bfef3acfcfaee6fb
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>

The main motivation for this change is to: (a) add missing CPU flags
(including those flags that provide mitigation for the recent CVE flaws)
as 'traits'; and (b) adjust and clean up the layout of the 'hw/cpu/'
directory.

To that end, the following are the rough set of changes in this patch.
(NB: Once we settle on the main content, I'm amenable to split them as
needed.)

(*) Introduce a new cpu/x86 directory; and vendor-specific files: amd.py
    and intel.py; with __init__.py containing the *common* stuff (

    - hw/cpu/x86/amd.py  (AMD-specific)
    - hw/cpu/x86/intel.py  (Intel-specific)
    - hw/cpu/x86/__init__.py  (Common for both AMD and Intel)

       ---

    - hw/cpy/x86.py  (Work out how to properly remove this file.
      Contents of these are moved into x86/__init__.py.  Aside: I learnt
      that it _is_ "valid" to have both x86.py, and x86/__init__.py; but
      we should "deprecate" this file, too, for clarity's sake.)
    - hw/cpu/amd.py  (Deprecate it with a comment.)

(*) Add various missing CPU flags to x86/intel.py and x86/amd.py

(*) Move, from x86.py, flags like "VMX" (Intel) and "SVM" (AMD) into
    corresponding vendor-specific files.

TODO: Comb-through all the flags again (especially the __init__.py) to
      make sure you got only the common stuff; and have *not* regressed

References:

[1] Thread start:
    http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-May/006281.html
    -- On reporting CPU flags that provide mitiation (to CVE flaws) as
    Nova 'traits'

[2] Thread conclusion:
    http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-May/006364.html

commit_message:
hw: cpu: Add certain missing traits

[Work In Progress]
                            ___......__             _
                        _.-'           ~-_       _.=a~~-_
--=====-.-.-_----------~   .--.       _   -.__.-~ ( ___==>
              '''--...__  (    \ \\\ { )       _.-~
                        =_ ~_  \\-~~~//~~~~-=-~
                         |-=-~_ \\   \\
                         |_/   =. )   ~}
                         |}      ||
                        //       ||
                      _//        {{
                   '='~'          \\_
                                   ~~'

                        - - -

The main motivation for this change is to: (a) add missing CPU flags
(including those flags that provide mitigation for the recent CVE flaws)
as 'traits'; and (b) adjust and clean up the layout of the 'hw/cpu/'
directory.

To that end, the following are the rough set of changes in this patch.
(NB: Once we settle on the main content, I'm amenable to split them as
needed.)

(*) Introduce a new cpu/x86 directory; and vendor-specific files: amd.py
    and intel.py; with __init__.py containing the *common* stuff (

    - hw/cpu/x86/amd.py  (AMD-specific)
    - hw/cpu/x86/intel.py  (Intel-specific)
    - hw/cpu/x86/__init__.py  (Common for both AMD and Intel)

       ---

    - hw/cpy/x86.py  (Contents of this file are moved into
      x86/__init__.py.)
    - hw/cpu/amd.py  (Deprecate it with a comment.)

(*) Add various missing CPU flags to x86/intel.py and x86/amd.py

(*) Move, from x86.py, flags like "VMX" (Intel) and "SVM" (AMD) into
    corresponding vendor-specific files.

References:

[1] Thread start:
    http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-May/006281.html
    -- On reporting CPU flags that provide mitiation (to CVE flaws) as
    Nova 'traits'

[2] Thread conclusion:
    http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-May/006364.html

Change-Id: I127ed21d249675a1a876379bfcdb436749bf108b
Signed-off-by: Kashyap Chamarthy <kchamart@redhat.com>

>  > https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/tests/un
> it/services/trunk/test_utils.py#L52
>
> "Because of" "interface" ;)

Sorry. I was probably tired when I was checking that :)

>
>  > https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/neutron/plugins/
> ml2/drivers/openvswitch/agent/openflow/native/ofswitch.py#L217
>
> done.'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2018-09-19 08:52:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review+2

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-09-19 17:22:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

>> Let me ask a question before dropping the option. Can operators
>> switch of_interface option from vsctl to native without dropping
>> traffic? Some operators need to care traffic drop even if it is a
>> short time. I heard switching the option caused traffic drop with
>> Pike or Queens release (though I had no time to dig into the detail
>> at that time).

> I heard such a story but haven't confirmed myself.

I tested this using the stein master branch of neutron and observed packet losses when changing of_interface.
I filed bug 1793354. If you drop of_interface now, it means packet losses are forced to happen if a deployer uses of_interface "ovs-ofctl" (to avoid potential packet losses).

I believe we need to investigate packet loss when changing of_interface option value before dropping this option.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2018-09-19 17:23:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

If packet losses are the intended behavior, it is better to ask opinions from operators at least.'}, {'account_id': 9200, 'date': '2018-09-20 07:35:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> I filed bug 1793354. If you drop of_interface now, it means packet
 > losses are forced to happen if a deployer uses of_interface
 > "ovs-ofctl" (to avoid potential packet losses).
 > 
 > I believe we need to investigate packet loss when changing
 > of_interface option value before dropping this option.

Thanks for the investigation. As I wrote in the bug page, I have no idea for a fix right now. ;('}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2018-09-20 08:17:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

> > I filed bug 1793354. If you drop of_interface now, it means
 > packet
 > > losses are forced to happen if a deployer uses of_interface
 > > "ovs-ofctl" (to avoid potential packet losses).
 > >
 > > I believe we need to investigate packet loss when changing
 > > of_interface option value before dropping this option.
 > 
 > Thanks for the investigation. As I wrote in the bug page, I have no
 > idea for a fix right now. ;(

According to Iwamoto's findings and his comment in bug 1793354 I think that we should add 
specific note about that in release note - maybe even in prelude section.
Also mail for operators ML to inform them would be useful.
But I think that we should finally remove this option.
Or if we will not be able to remove it completely, maybe at least we should remove this "not native" variant from tests scenarios.'}, {'account_id': 27654, 'date': '2018-09-20 21:21:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> If packet losses are the intended behavior, it is better to ask
 > opinions from operators at least.

I can confirm the packet losses behavior by following the reproducing steps provided by the bug report. I think it is fine because the general expectation is a few hours downtime when operators are doing the upgrade. However, it doesn't hurt to ask though.

We definitely needed to mention packet losses behavior in somewhere, perhaps in the release note and/or the administrator guide."}, {'account_id': 27654, 'date': '2018-09-20 21:58:40.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> > If packet losses are the intended behavior, it is better to ask
 > > opinions from operators at least.
 > 
 > I can confirm the packet losses behavior by following the
 > reproducing steps provided by the bug report. I think it is fine
 > because the general expectation is a few hours downtime when
 > operators are doing the upgrade. However, it doesn't hurt to ask
 > though.
 > 
 > We definitely needed to mention packet losses behavior in
 > somewhere, perhaps in the release note and/or the administrator
 > guide.

I pushed a patch to mention the packet losses behavior: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/604228/ . If neutron cannot deal with the packet loss behavior, we can proceed with merging above patch."}, {'account_id': 9200, 'date': '2018-09-21 01:37:51.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Sent a mail to the mailing lists. Let's see."}, {'account_id': 21798, 'date': '2018-09-21 15:37:59.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review+1

+1 on seeing progress on this and looking at patch, let's see what reactions the ML post brings"}, {'account_id': 27654, 'date': '2018-09-21 15:39:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

As a record, this is the ML: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-operators/2018-September/015923.html'}, {'account_id': 9373, 'date': '2018-09-22 19:24:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

Changing ovs-ofctl to native may break some deployments with different physical networks with the same mac addresses. This is relates to the calculation of the datapath id based on bridge mac.

Please see https://bugs.launchpad.net/neutron/+bug/1697243 , this bug is still unresolved.

I think this should be mentioned somewhere.'}, {'account_id': 11975, 'date': '2018-10-15 21:52:27.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Code-Review+2 by Slawek Kaplonski <skaplons@redhat.com>
'}, {'account_id': 16688, 'date': '2019-05-04 17:03:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5:

Bug 1697243 is solved and cherry-picked up to Queens.

As commented in Denver PTG, we should move on and merge this patch.'}, {'account_id': 9373, 'date': '2019-05-04 17:06:24.000000000', 'content': 'Removed Code-Review-1 by Vlad Gusev <vlad.esten@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Drop of_interface option

Default value for "of_interface" config option was switched
to "native" in Pike release.
In the same release this option was deprecated to removal.
Now it's time to remove it and force use of "native" driver to
manage openflows.

Change-Id: Ic900209868acfbe3bbb56fabbbf5c4472857e412
Co-Authored-By: Ihar Hrachyshka <ihrachys@redhat.com>
Co-Authored-By: Slawek Kaplonski <skaplons@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix allowed address pair validation

Neutron requires the allowed address pair ip address to be
either an ip or a cidr.
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/575265/ made heat verify for
cidr only.

Change-Id: I2cc2785cb32cf8d788af6262992b1b76107c8292
Story: 2005674
Task: 30985

run-dell-emc-vmax'}, {'account_id': 9535, 'date': '2019-04-26 10:48:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review-1

I have run a normal scenario and I like the old numbers better.

Scenario is:
  Total: 100G
  Free: 10G
  Over subscription ratio: 20
  Reserved: 10%

With the old calculation we would get 100G available as adjusted_free_virtual, but with the new calculation it would be 1715G, which seems a little excessive given the real free space.

In my opinion I prefer the old calculation because it's an adaptive calculation that is less likely to result in a broken system.

Looking back at my notes in the LP bug, I think the cleanest approach is to modify the `consume_from_volume` method and the callers so it acts differently for thin provisioned volumes.

I could be wrong, but I think if we can pass the thin provisioning argument to the method, replacing it with the following code would fix the problem:

    def consume_from_volume(self, volume, update_time=True, is_thin=False):
        """Incrementally update host state from a volume."""
        volume_gb = volume['size']
        self.allocated_capacity_gb += volume_gb
        self.provisioned_capacity_gb += volume_gb
        if self.free_capacity_gb == 'infinite':
            # There's virtually infinite space on back-end
            pass
        elif self.free_capacity_gb == 'unknown':
            # Unable to determine the actual free space on back-end
            pass
        else:
            # Assume thin volumes will only consume the over subscription ratio
            # Drivers will update us with real values later on
            if is_thin:
                volume_gb /= float(self.max_over_subscription_ratio)
            # volume_gb should never be greater than free_capacity_gb, but even 
            # if it does and the error is in the thousandths, we don't want to
            # show a negative value anywhere.
            self.free_capacity_gb -= min(volume_gb, self.free_capacity_gb)
        if update_time:
            self.updated = timeutils.utcnow()
        LOG.debug("Consumed %s GB from backend: %s", volume['size'], self)'}, {'account_id': 14624, 'date': '2019-04-28 09:51:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

run-dell-emc-vmax'}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2019-04-29 08:48:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> With the old calculation we would get 100G available as adjusted_free_virtual, but with the new calculation it would be 1715G, which seems a little excessive given the real free space.
> In my opinion I prefer the old calculation because it's an adaptive calculation that is less likely to result in a broken system.

Yeah 1715G is a way too much :-) but I think the issue is on applying a ratio of 20 (what 20 does mean?). Like I'm not quite sure on how you come to 100G with this ratio. Also, what would happen if we schedule a disk of 11G in your scenario?

I probably missed something because I don't understand why you don't see the issue...

If you have a disk of 10G and apply ratio of 2, you are expecting to be able to schedule 20 volumes of 1G, right ? not still 10 of 1G :-)"}, {'account_id': 9535, 'date': '2019-05-08 12:49:18.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> Yeah 1715G is a way too much :-) but I think the issue is on
 > applying a ratio of 20 (what 20 does mean?). Like I'm not quite

20 is the over provisioning ratio.  We are expecting our storage to be under used by a factor greater than 20.
 

 > sure on how you come to 100G with this ratio. Also, what would

100G is what you get when you run the current code with the values I mentioned. 

 > happen if we schedule a disk of 11G in your scenario?
 >

It would succeed, since it's less than 100G.

 
 > I probably missed something because I don't understand why you
 > don't see the issue...
 > 

What issue?  The negative returned value? Or the fact that Cinder scheduler doesn't follow the standard over-provisioning formula?

The negative value is easy to fix, the code I provided in a previous comment fixes it.

Changing the over-provisioning algorithm we use is a completely different matter, and one that we've discussed before and is not tightly coupled to fixing the negative value (that looks terrible).


 > If you have a disk of 10G and apply ratio of 2, you are expecting
 > to be able to schedule 20 volumes of 1G, right ? not still 10 of 1G
 > :-)

That is the standard formula, not Cinder's.  As I mentioned, we have a different formula that dynamically adapts to the reality."}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2019-05-17 08:13:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> 20 is the over provisioning ratio.  We are expecting our storage to be under used by a factor greater than 20.

I understand it's the ratio, but what Operator can expect when setting this to 20? The operator does not have any idea of what would be the result.

> It would succeed, since it's less than 100G.

It will but you would not be able to schedule anything else... Since next time 'free' will be equal to 10G - 11G  = -1G [0], then you will apply the ratio: -1 * 20 which is -20G. So basically that does not provide the expected virtual 100G.

The other way we could fix the issue is to avoid subtracting to 'free' the volumes scheduled, so 'free' will just increase based on the usage and we apply the ratio on it, so basically even if we schedule that 11G vol, since it's empty, 'free' remains 10G.

[0] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/scheduler/host_manager.py#L313"}, {'account_id': 20721, 'date': '2019-05-17 15:57:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

run-Datera'}, {'account_id': 10058, 'date': '2019-05-17 19:06:14.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Sahid, I think I understand your confusion. In Gorka's scenario, it would actually schedule anything as:
...
free = free_space - math.floor(total * reserved)
...

So, free=0. About not consuming from the volume at volume's creation, that might pose a risk as you can create way too many volumes without being able to control.

I think Gorkas proposal its a good solution. We consume from the volume proportionally to the max_over_provisioned_ratio."}, {'account_id': 7730, 'date': '2019-05-21 09:56:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Hello Erlon, Thanks for jumping on it.

I'm not sure to understand how you come to free=0 and even with free equal 0 when we apply the ratio we can't schedule anything else [0].

My thinking is that with Gorka fix that does not work either, free will be equal to '0 - math.floor(100*0.1)' which means -10.

That because based on its fix, free_capacity will be equal to 'free_capacity - free_capacity' since volume_gb is 11 and free_capacity was 10.

In my POV trying to remove the negative value as suggested by Gorka is not appropriate we should fix the root cause. Also, that does not fix the problem that the Operator does not have any idea of what would be the result when setting an oversubscription-ratio since the result will be based on what users are scheduling.

[0] https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/master/cinder/scheduler/filters/capacity_filter.py#L156"}, {'account_id': 10058, 'date': '2019-05-27 14:38:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

Hey Sahid, no problem.

I had a typo in my last message,
"it would actually schedule anything" -> "it wouldn't actually schedule anything".
Sorry about this.

I mention about the scenario Gorka mentioned:
  Total: 100G
  Free: 10G
  Over subscription ratio: 20
  Reserved: 10%

The scheduler formula to compute the free space is currently:

free = free_space - math.floor(total * reserved)
So, free=0.

I agree with you that we should fix the root of the probem, and for me that is how we
decrement the free space. We must fix consume_from_volume[1] not allow free space
be negative and proportionally decrement the free_capacity considering
max_over_subscription_ratio. This is what Gorka is proposing in the snippet.

See that these decrement calculations will only live for a short time as after
the volume driver updates the new volumes from the storage, this value will be
set to the most updated, reflecting what there is in the storage.

[1] http://bit.ly/2WpHk1P'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-09 09:41:52.000000000', 'message': 'scheduler: fix virtual free space with over-subscription

The current algorithm is computing the virtual free space available
based on the current usage which could be negative (that from a
previous volume scheduled using over-subscription).

This way to compute whether the backend can handle the requested
volume creates false errors.

To fix the issue the virtual space available is now computed based on
the available space that we add the over-subscription ratio, remove
the reserved space and the current used space.

Change-Id: I6a98bc1d376ba2172f60510f0528812cd69048e6
Closes-bug: #1741275

commit_message:
scheduler: fix virtual free space with over-subscription

The current algorithm is computing the virtual free space available
based on the current usage which could be negative (that from the
previous volume scheduled using over-subscription).

This way to compute whether the backend can handle the requested
volume creates false errors.

To fix the issue the virtual space available is now computed based on
the available space that we add the over-subscription ratio, remove
the reserved space and the currently used space.

Change-Id: I6a98bc1d376ba2172f60510f0528812cd69048e6
Closes-bug: #1741275
Signed-off-by: Sahid Orentino Ferdjaoui <sahid.ferdjaoui@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Fix internal TLS issue with composable networks.

The 'tenant' network was always filtered when setting
up the 'ApacheNetworks' value. This should have filtered
all networks without a VIP.

Closes-Bug: #1830622
Change-Id: Ifc5f00d75258ebfefd5fc972151450f1d0462911

commit_message:
Update UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE for stable/stein

Update the URL to the upper-constraints file to point to the redirect
rule on releases.openstack.org so that anyone working on this branch
will switch to the correct upper-constraints list automatically when
the requirements repository branches.

Until the requirements repository has as stable/stein branch, tests will
continue to use the upper-constraints list on master.

Change-Id: I802310398add2d61f71a570f106108bff0452053

commit_message:
standalone/undercloud - post: use EndpointMap to fetch Keystone URL

Using EndpointMap to ensure we get the hostname/fqdn if possible
otherwise it fallbacks to the IP for Keystone public endpoint.

This is useful when the operator uses a certificate based on
hostname/fqdn and not an IP address.

Closes-Bug #1763776

(cherry picked from commit 016279b71e74700c18f2270649cb7567ae94505f)
Depends-On: I1c222fce178e164432acbfaeda8695c3cf7a6e98 
Change-Id: Id8e1c6408ee6a322c61de90a52ab1eacaf0dba88

commit_message:
yum: add liboath to packages installed from EPEL

We limit the number of packages installed from EPEL to avoid any
conflicts and one of those packages that was recently added was
liboath.

Change-Id: I14b3f3f58ca210ad396d9e434cc26d6b1c50b8a1
Closes-Bug: #1824890
(cherry picked from commit d760aa2b5d6d9603313dd3621061df5ba604dd70)

commit_message:
aodh-api: use aodh::config to configure Aodh API when possible

Rely on aodh::config class to configure Aodh API related parameters.
That way, we don't need to include aodh::api in the puppet profile
anymore.

Depends-On: Ia008917475edcd086fb5076fab320206d05ea557
Change-Id: Ia66a4192a179c356f85924323de590ff921bd539

commit_message:
Deployment: Properly pick bootstrap node per role

Previous logic for identifying bootstrap node results in broken
deployments where bootstrap tasks have to run also on other node
than just controller-0. This fix is queens only.

Change-Id: I752441565641ef85f7ac0d8f2d7234a6630c0e3f
Resolves: rhbz#1599764
Closes-Bug: #1828590

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-05-23 19:40:04.000000000', 'message': 'Fix run-os-net-config.sh to use ping6 for IPv6 hostnames

The run-os-net-config.sh script checks to see if an IP address is
IPv4 or IPv6, and uses ping or ping6 accordingly. This change also
resolves hostnames and submits the resolved IP to the same test.
If the hostname only resolves to an IPv6 address, then ping6 will
be used.

Change-Id: I9f37992157935b37cc9beb8a2f3b9d749a62bd1b
Closes-bug: 1830274
'}]
commit_message:
Fix run-os-net-config.sh to use ping6 for IPv6 hostnames

The run-os-net-config.sh script checks to see if an IP address is
IPv4 or IPv6, and uses ping or ping6 accordingly. This change also
resolves hostnames and submits the resolved IP to the same test.
If the hostname only resolves to an IPv6 address, then ping6 will
be used.

Change-Id: I9f37992157935b37cc9beb8a2f3b9d749a62bd1b
Closes-bug: 1830274

commit_message:
Add Upstream Institute training image repo under Docs

Adding the repository containing the files for the VM image we use for the
OpenStack Upstream Institute training. As the OpenDev changes are taking place
soon the intent is to have the training relevant repositories under one umbrella
to avoid future confusions on where the resources are and where they belong.

Change-Id: I6271a3034ba00e37f90b344af814ecdeac196b05

[{'created': '2019-04-23 01:53:23.000000000', 'message': 'Fix sriov driver leaking resources and exceptions

ipdb instances were not properly closed in connect() call, leading to
hanging references being left open to container namespaces. This led to
sriov vf not getting released even after the pods that requested the
vfs were deleted.

Also, earlier release_lock_object() was supressing exceptions due to
return statement in the finally block.

Change-Id: I3ae4cbde638fe12dc925d5489b5e002e573c0a83
Resolves-Bug: 1825916
Signed-off-by: Yash Gupta <y.gupta@samsung.com>

commit_message:
Fix sriov driver leaking resources and exceptions

ipdb instances were not properly closed in connect() call, leading to
hanging references being left open to container namespaces. This led to
sriov vf not getting released even after the pods that requested the
vfs were deleted.

Also, earlier release_lock_object() was supressing exceptions due to
return statement in the finally block.

Change-Id: I3ae4cbde638fe12dc925d5489b5e002e573c0a83
Resolves-Bug: 1825916
Signed-off-by: Yash Gupta <y.gupta@samsung.com>

More information is needed for this at the commit message. Also, I suppose this needs to be linked to a blueprint, as well as adding related documentation. Other than that, code looks good'}, {'account_id': 30247, 'date': '2019-04-30 09:54:56.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 15:

> More information is needed for this at the commit message. Also, I
 > suppose this needs to be linked to a blueprint, as well as adding
 > related documentation. Other than that, code looks good

Hi. Thanks for suggestions. We'll take a bit different approach. This patch and the next one ( https://review.opendev.org/#/c/656482 ) will be linked with bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/kuryr-kubernetes/+bug/1826865 . Documentation update about enabling feature gate and kubelet_root_dir will be added in the next patch along with starting using the PodResourcesClient. This patch only adds infra without really using it, so it's not the right place for documentation. However, I'll add some more information to the commit-message."}, {'account_id': 24604, 'date': '2019-04-30 11:11:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 16.'}, {'account_id': 30247, 'date': '2019-04-30 13:30:18.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to bug/1826865'}, {'account_id': 30247, 'date': '2019-05-08 08:28:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 16:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-04-10 15:22:14.000000000', 'message': 'Add PodResources service client

PodResources client could be used by sriov cni to obtain
devices allocated for container by sriov device-plugin.

KubeletPodResources service is still in alpha, so it should be
explicitly enabled in kubelet feature-gates.

Change-Id: Icf088b839db079efe9c7647c31be4ead867ed32b
Signed-off-by: Ilya Maximets <i.maximets@samsung.com>

'}, {'created': '2019-04-30 11:11:32.000000000', 'message': "Add PodResources service client

PodResources client could be used by sriov cni to obtain devices
allocated for container by sriov device-plugin.

KubeletPodResources service is still in alpha, so it should be
explicitly enabled in kubelet feature-gates:
    kubelet --feature-gates KubeletPodResources=true

New config option 'kubelet_root_dir' added to 'sriov' section
that defaults to kubelet default root-dir '/var/lib/kulelet'.
In case kubelet started with non-default root directory passed
via '--root-dir' option, the same value should be configured
in 'kubelet_root_dir'.
Note that if sriov binding driver will be used inside container
'kubelet_root_dir'/pod-resources directory should be mounted
to this container in order to allow communication with kubelet
via gRPC protocol over the unix domain socket.

Partial-Bug: 1826865
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/652629
Change-Id: Icf088b839db079efe9c7647c31be4ead867ed32b
Signed-off-by: Ilya Maximets <i.maximets@samsung.com>

allocated for container by sriov device-plugin.

that defaults to kubelet default root-dir '/var/lib/kulelet'.
In case kubelet started with non-default root directory passed
via '--root-dir' option, the same value should be configured
in 'kubelet_root_dir'.

commit_message:
Add PodResources service client

PodResources client could be used by sriov cni to obtain devices
allocated for container by sriov device-plugin.

KubeletPodResources service is still in alpha, so it should be
explicitly enabled in kubelet feature-gates:
    kubelet --feature-gates KubeletPodResources=true

New config option 'kubelet_root_dir' added to 'sriov' section
that defaults to kubelet default root-dir '/var/lib/kulelet'.
In case kubelet started with non-default root directory passed
via '--root-dir' option, the same value should be configured
in 'kubelet_root_dir'.
Note that if sriov binding driver will be used inside container
'kubelet_root_dir'/pod-resources directory should be mounted
to this container in order to allow communication with kubelet
via gRPC protocol over the unix domain socket.

Partial-Bug: 1826865
Depends-On: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/652629
Change-Id: Icf088b839db079efe9c7647c31be4ead867ed32b
Signed-off-by: Ilya Maximets <i.maximets@samsung.com>

commit_message:
Use stable ARA setup interface for defining the callback location

ARA ships simple setup modules to help figure out the paths
to where things are located.
These are backwards compatible from ARA 1.0 to 0.x.

Change-Id: I2bcbff3b028a036dfcf213154b1c4db5c3f5a6b0
(cherry picked from commit 40e26e69cee9e42183d8e88c3b3cc177e7966b1a)

commit_message:
Gather fail/pass after executor is done

Instead of counting rotations (or failovers) as finished even
though they may not have finished its better to actually use the
executor futures to call a callback that will be called when the
actual work is done and use that instead to then LOG the correct
value instead of the potentially incorrect one.

Change-Id: I10dedf459822cb8608706b7243e699e42ad8d99a

commit_message:
Use stable ARA setup interface for defining the callback location

ARA ships simple setup modules to help figure out the paths to where
things are located.
These are backwards compatible from ARA 1.0 to 0.x.

Change-Id: I587bc1af8c05159a63f972fef14e2550287047aa

commit_message:
Complete angular translation extract pattern

Currently AngularGettextHTMLParser parses translations of form
{$ 'content' | translate $}. However, there is another form in
projects' html files: {$ ::'content' | translate $}.

This commit fine-tunes the filter_regex and related handle_xxx
functions to extract both forms of translations.

Closes-Bug: #1824644
Change-Id: I7129a13d046b699328b77267ae4936d31af8144c
(cherry picked from commit 5de40b3f397f812d5236a274b22515b18118015c)

[{'created': '2019-04-26 13:43:15.000000000', 'message': "Ensure Pod SG is updated on podSelector of NP spec update

When the podSelector of a Network Policy Spec is updated from '{}'
to any other value, the pods that are not supposed to be enforced
by the policy anymore do not have their Security Group updated
to the default one. This commit fixes the issue by also taking into
account the possible value of '{}' in the podSelector NP spec.

Change-Id: I35519acfdf8ef250880e36bcf789c063ba86b31e
Closes-Bug: 1826548
"}, {'created': '2019-05-07 09:55:06.000000000', 'message': "Ensure Pod SG is updated on podSelector of NP spec update

When the podSelector of a Network Policy Spec is updated from '{}'
to any other value, the pods that are not supposed to be enforced
by the policy anymore do not have their Security Group updated
to the default one. This commit fixes the issue by also taking into
account the possible value of '{}' in the podSelector NP spec.

Change-Id: I35519acfdf8ef250880e36bcf789c063ba86b31e
Closes-Bug: 1826548
"}]
commit_message:
Ensure Pod SG is updated on podSelector of NP spec update

When the podSelector of a Network Policy Spec is updated from '{}'
to any other value, the pods that are not supposed to be enforced
by the policy anymore do not have their Security Group updated
to the default one. This commit fixes the issue by also taking into
account the possible value of '{}' in the podSelector NP spec.

Change-Id: I35519acfdf8ef250880e36bcf789c063ba86b31e
Closes-Bug: 1826548

commit_message:
Clarify supported SUSE versions

This role only support openSUSE Leap 15, not 42.3, not tumbleweed.
Saying all is confusing and a bad practice. This fixes it, while
ensuring the job is properly defined to test that assertion.

Change-Id: Icbe93a7c35d59cff18f549c0e193beaf7f879cc2

commit_message:
Clarify supported SUSE versions

This role only support openSUSE Leap 15, not 42.3, not tumbleweed.
Saying all is confusing and a bad practice. This fixes it, while
ensuring the job is properly defined to test that assertion.

Change-Id: Icd9692dc33749f7fb79e61be73e7fdd6bc8d15dc

> Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.

commit_message:
Add relnote on cinderclient minver bump to 4.0.1

A fix for bug 1824017 bumped the minimum version requirement of
python-cinderclient to 4.0.0. The fix was backported to stable/stein,
so the minimum version bump should be covered by a release note.

python-cinderclient requirement is bumped to >=4.0.1
as 4.0.0 is blocked by global-requirements.txt [1].

It was suggested by the release team in the review of
horizon stein update release [2].

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/src/commit/1baf07a77333fc57d9d4a669d0265b0e687fd031/global-requirements.txt#L256
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/655447/

Change-Id: I2b43e159da7e58980b2810a104ae2418f237d1c7
Related-Bug: #1824017
(cherry picked from commit e3c600cbbf5b0ca09f9c0d66e7a212dd46b36a4a)

subject: Adds compute-hyperv to Winstackers
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 1004, 'name': 'Mohammed Naser', 'email': 'mnaser@vexxhost.com', 'username': 'mnaser'}, {'_account_id': 2472, 'name': 'Doug Hellmann', 'email': 'dhellmann@redhat.com', 'username': 'doug-hellmann'}, {'_account_id': 4257, 'name': 'Zane Bitter', 'email': 'zbitter@redhat.com', 'username': 'zaneb'}, {'_account_id': 5263, 'name': 'Jeremy Stanley', 'display_name': 'fungi', 'email': 'fungi@yuggoth.org', 'username': 'fungi', 'status': 'missing, presumed fed'}, {'_account_id': 8099, 'name': 'Graham Hayes', 'email': 'gr@ham.ie', 'username': 'graham'}, {'_account_id': 8213, 'name': 'Claudiu Belu', 'email': 'cbelu@cloudbasesolutions.com', 'username': 'claudiub'}, {'_account_id': 8543, 'name': 'Lucian Petrut', 'email': 'lpetrut@cloudbasesolutions.com', 'username': 'plucian'}, {'_account_id': 10607, 'name': 'Alexandra Settle', 'email': 'a.settle@outlook.com', 'username': 'asettle'}, {'_account_id': 12404, 'name': 'Rico Lin', 'email': 'ricolin@ricolky.com', 'username': 'rico.lin'}, {'_account_id': 14070, 'name': 'Eric Fried', 'email': 'openstack@fried.cc', 'username': 'efried'}, {'_account_id': 17068, 'name': 'Jean-Philippe Evrard', 'email': 'openstack@a.spamming.party', 'username': 'evrardjp'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 8213, 'date': '2019-04-24 16:01:45.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 8213, 'date': '2019-04-24 16:05:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

PS: There is a precedent for this set by PowerVMStackers, as nova-powervm was added to their governance.'}, {'account_id': 8213, 'date': '2019-04-24 16:42:09.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-04-25 15:01:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)

So the potentially tricky part of the request here is that there is a hyperv driver for Nova in Nova mainline code, and this is a more advanced version of the driver than the one in mainline.

There is indeed a precedent with the powervm driver, but it still bothers me that we'd have two competing "official" hyperv and powervm drivers. From a user perspective that is very confusing...'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-04-25 20:27:10.000000000', 'content': 'Topic set to project-update'}, {'account_id': 8543, 'date': '2019-05-02 10:59:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

At the very least, those two drivers shouldn't be treated differently.

To bring some context, we had to go with an out of tree driver in order to merge patches in a timely manner. The upstream driver was falling behind, both in terms of features as well as unfixed bugs. Some patches weren't receiving any reviews in months, effectively taking years to merge. That was a bit longer than our customers could wait, so all of them are now using the out of tree driver.

We had to keep the upstream driver as well so that Nova would continue to officially support Windows/Hyper-V, otherwise anyone could introduce breaking changes. We've been focusing on the downstream driver, yet still porting critical bug fixes as well as some trivial features, simple enough to be merged in a timely manner. Our Nova CI validates the upstream driver while for other projects (e.g. Cinder CI, Neutron CI, etc) we're using the downstream driver.

The attitude towards out of tree drivers seems to have changed over the last years. Some time ago, drivers were requested to use the "nova.virt" namespace, which was expected to cause some trouble for out of tree drivers, someone even saying "you're not supposed to use out of tree drivers anyway". Nowadays Nova cores seem to acknowledge those drivers, being kind enough not to break them (e.g. by keeping some compatibility layers for one release). One idea that was mentioned on the PTG etherpad and is brought up every now and then is stabilizing the driver interface and encouraging out of tree drivers, which applies to other projects as well.

Until this subject is settled, IMO those two drivers should be given equal chances to thrive outside the Nova tree yet still being considered Openstack projects. I'd say that it's in the end user's best interest, the fact that they're able to choose shouldn't be seen as a disadvantage.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-05-09 15:29:51.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Yes I understand why you had to do it and the problem is solves... just wanted to give some extra context for TC members to form an opinion on it.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-05-16 17:20:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

I'm not happy about this situation. I don't think anybody is happy about the situation.

But the situation is caused by forcing people to deal with a bunch of bureaucratic BS that doesn't reflect the situation on the ground. The TC isn't in a position to change all of that, but we are in a position to change this bit: to make the recommended driver for a nominally officially-supported feature of OpenStack an official part of OpenStack.

I hope this won't be the last step, but it's the only one the TC has any real influence over."}, {'account_id': 12404, 'date': '2019-05-20 08:43:48.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Agree this is not ideal for anyone, and to push it down and force join is not ideal too. But if there is no document, plan, or action to help users understand these two part together, I can tell how that might confuse users. I'm fine to give a +1 on rollcall if there are at least some document to help users here."}, {'account_id': 8543, 'date': '2019-05-20 09:08:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

@Rico thanks for feedback. The out of tree driver is documented here [1], which also describes its relationship with the upstream driver. Please let me know if there's anything else that we should add or if there's some other place where this should be mentioned.

[1] https://compute-hyperv.readthedocs.io/en/latest/install/index.html"}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-05-20 12:09:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

Agreed with Zane. Pushing towards his direction.'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-05-21 13:48:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

There is a longer term issue to deal with - but for the immediate problem, we should add this to openstack/ - there is a group of people working with the four opens, on an OpenStack deliverable.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-05-22 09:04:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

As much as I'd prefer a single driver, I understand that artificially keeping that deliverable out of the team's deliverables is not helping anyone"}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-05-22 13:28:58.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from project-update to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-05-22 13:37:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

I think the sentiment is clear here - we'd rather not, but let's do this to make everyone's life just that little bit easier."}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-05-22 13:38:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I'm curious to hear whether members of the Nova team have any concerns, or what their long-term plans for the in-tree driver would be with the addition of this project."}, {'account_id': 2472, 'date': '2019-05-22 14:27:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1

I added Eric as a reviewer on this to get the Nova team's input, but I support going ahead while the testing issue is resolved."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-22 20:02:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1

Agree compute-hyperv should be under Winstackers governance, and be named openstack/compute-hyperv (or openstack/nova-hyperv) to mirror how PowerVM is working.

I am quite familiar with the relative merits and pitfalls of out-of-tree drivers. They're way easier to maintain for production purposes because you don't need Nova's blessing to merge code. Nova is notoriously understaffed as well as, ahem, "careful".

That said, it's weird, but having an in-tree driver at least nominally maintained and kept CI-green - even if nobody ever actually uses it - makes it easier to maintain the out-of-tree driver because Nova will think about and even ask you before they break something.

I will say that comments about patches being ignored or taking forever to merge might be outdated. Put another way, "you haven't tried lately": https://review.opendev.org/#/q/project:openstack/nova+path:%255Enova/virt/hyperv/.*+status:open

Anyway, this is the right thing to do, or at least the start of it, given the way things are.'}, {'account_id': 5263, 'date': '2019-05-22 21:45:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-05-27 08:15:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2: Rollcall-Vote+1 Workflow+1

Please provide a patch once it's been moved out of the x/ namespace."}]

commit_message:
Adds compute-hyperv to Winstackers

The compute-hyperv project has been around for a while, but it was not under
the Winstackers governance.

[1]: https://github.com/openstack/compute-hyperv
[2]: https://bugs.launchpad.net/compute-hyperv

Change-Id: I670837beb85f52988aa12a7fe610e124b4707600

messages: [{'account_id': 26297, 'date': '2018-06-09 07:57:07.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 17499, 'date': '2018-08-15 09:08:33.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 28543, 'date': '2018-09-26 12:05:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 17499, 'date': '2019-01-24 08:50:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Patch Set 1 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 28239, 'date': '2019-01-24 09:16:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 28614, 'date': '2019-02-11 13:20:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 26285, 'date': '2019-02-13 15:05:05.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 26297, 'date': '2019-05-27 08:02:03.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2018-06-09 07:57:07.000000000', 'message': 'fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I44729904db9271f333050aaadeec7886cfecb642
'}, {'created': '2019-01-24 08:50:42.000000000', 'message': 'fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that

Change-Id: I44729904db9271f333050aaadeec7886cfecb642

commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I44729904db9271f333050aaadeec7886cfecb642

commit_message:
Constraint networkx to <2.3 for Python 2

 NetworkX released 2.3, dropping support for Python 2.

 https://github.com/networkx/networkx/blob/master/doc/news.rst

 Also see I0a9700926c9a0db93e782c853c33f1aaee3d4876

 fixed sphinx requirements also according to global requirements
 
 jsonschema should be uncaped also according to global requirements
 but there are conflicts with zakarclient designateclient and irconicclient
 
 so for now I put it in remark

Change-Id: Iea3dbcfa1f6ddf2c413ede5e73fa076c6edccfdf

When running tox, it creates the .eggs folder and leaves the repo
reporting that it's in a non-clean state.

commit_message:
tools: report dissenting votes for project-update

If there is a project-update change where we have a -1 code review,
we should probably put that into account as it might mean that it's
not the good time to land it.

Change-Id: If95af41005a0b328ffbda74f6b56b00d68a98eea

commit_message:
Update min tox version to 2.0

The commands used by constraints need at least tox 2.0.  Update to
reflect reality, which should help with local running of constraints
targets.

Change-Id: Ifd24a82fdfc57c38414212866611cf0b9fe1b3c8
Closes-Bug:  #1802030

commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I32d7895caa580e8f7611290baa297bcf2196b28d
Closes-Bug:  #1801657

commit_message:
Update uw_apache to run against bionic

uw_apache test was runned against xenial, which is not currrently
supported, due to which job was updated to run on bionic nodeset.

We also need to enable proxy_uwsgi for debian based distros.

Co-Authored-By: Guilherme Steinmuller Pimentel <gsteinmuller@vexxhost.com>
Co-Authored-By: Marc Gariépy <gariepy.marc@gmail.com>
Change-Id: Ibff3aa2a1ac1bbf2493aaf2419ee1e4dd763934c

commit_message:
fix tox python3 overrides

We want to default to running all tox environments under python 3, so
set the basepython value in each environment.

We do not want to specify a minor version number, because we do not
want to have to update the file every time we upgrade python.

We do not want to set the override once in testenv, because that
breaks the more specific versions used in default environments like
py35 and py36.

Change-Id: I7af22561a2792571951bf02eba841a296e6455c2
Closes-Bug:  #1801657

commit_message:
Bring back the --serial flag alive

https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/
openstack-ansible-os_tempest/tree/tasks/tempest_run.yml#n24
Syntex is correct, but --serial flag was not getting exposed in
rocky/master os_tempest tempest_run playbook, It refactors
the shell script and nicer so that it works perfectly.

openSUSE 42.3 testing is also removed since 42.3 is almost EOL and
building LXC containers is broken.

Change-Id: Ieca5103f803778a44bbb517954b56a9069babbdd
(cherry picked from commit 8794a6641bb466ceb5395935d169e85b698a034f)

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 5754, 'name': 'Alex Xu', 'email': 'hejie.xu@intel.com', 'username': 'xuhj'}, {'_account_id': 6873, 'name': 'Matt Riedemann', 'email': 'mriedem.os@gmail.com', 'username': 'mriedem'}, {'_account_id': 7730, 'name': 'Sahid Orentino Ferdjaoui', 'email': 'sahid.ferdjaoui@industrialdiscipline.com', 'username': 'sahid'}, {'_account_id': 11347, 'name': 'Rui Zang', 'email': 'rui.zang@yandex.com', 'username': 'rzang'}, {'_account_id': 11604, 'name': 'sean mooney', 'email': 'smooney@redhat.com', 'username': 'sean-k-mooney'}, {'_account_id': 14070, 'name': 'Eric Fried', 'email': 'openstack@fried.cc', 'username': 'efried'}, {'_account_id': 17261, 'name': 'guochunting', 'email': 'guochunting@inspur.com', 'username': 'friendgct'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 22378, 'name': 'Kaiyuan Qi', 'email': 'qiky@inspur.com', 'username': 'qiky'}, {'_account_id': 23360, 'name': 'Eric Lei', 'email': 'leiyashuai@inspur.com', 'username': 'leiyashuai'}, {'_account_id': 26458, 'name': 'Brin Zhang', 'email': 'zhangbailin@inspur.com', 'username': 'zhangbailin'}]

[{'account_id': 11347, 'date': '2018-12-05 08:38:53.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11347, 'date': '2018-12-10 07:25:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 11347, 'date': '2019-01-03 08:31:57.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from topic/pmem-specs to bp/virtual-persistent-memory'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-01-07 06:38:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

this is a fairly soft -1 the main concern being the
credentials used by the daxio utility and how we specify
the ssh key in particular.'}, {'account_id': 11347, 'date': '2019-01-07 16:43:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(6 comments)

Hey, Sean, thank you very much for the valuable comments.'}, {'account_id': 11347, 'date': '2019-01-08 15:08:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 11347, 'date': '2019-01-08 15:08:42.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11347, 'date': '2019-01-08 15:33:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 17261, 'date': '2019-02-22 00:36:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11347, 'date': '2019-03-19 05:11:20.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-03-19 17:18:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

Simple add-on to the main doc.

But...

I'm wondering at the dividing line between the generic and libvirt-specific parts of this blueprint. For instance, either there's nothing libvirt-specific about the pmem concept in general - including the way we're going to model it in placement - in which case the conf options should be defined in a non-libvirt-specific group so they can be reused by other drivers; or it's entirely libvirt-specific and we should just consolidate the two documents.

So which is it?"}, {'account_id': 11347, 'date': '2019-03-20 07:00:26.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

> Simple add-on to the main doc.
 > 
 > But...
 > 
 > I'm wondering at the dividing line between the generic and
 > libvirt-specific parts of this blueprint. For instance, either
 > there's nothing libvirt-specific about the pmem concept in general
 > - including the way we're going to model it in placement - in which
 > case the conf options should be defined in a non-libvirt-specific
 > group so they can be reused by other drivers; or it's entirely
 > libvirt-specific and we should just consolidate the two documents.
 > 
 > So which is it?

It is more like the first. PMEM concept is in general, so the main spec. However, the PMEM concept can be implement by multiple drivers. We just enable the libvirt driver. Thus this spec.
The main spec regulates the drivers should report the PMEM namespaces to placement, as to how, it is left to each independent driver implementation. Each driver may take its most convenient way to specify the configs and create namespaces accordingly.
To be specific, the PMEM namespace configuration is put into the libvirt section of the config file. Yes, the config format itself can be promoted to the main spec, however, I do not see much difference as leaving it to the drivers.

Thanks a lot for the review!"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-04-09 16:30:30.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 5:

Do we really need a spec for the low level implementation? Why can't sufficient detail be in https://review.openstack.org/#/c/601596/? Or at the very least this should be rebased on top of https://review.openstack.org/#/c/601596/ since there is a logical dependency."}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-04-18 05:38:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2019-04-24 04:11:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 5: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Yea, I also feel this is useless now. In the previous PTG, we want to separate the virt driver implementation detail out of the main spec. But yes, in the end, the virt driver implementation is pretty light, maybe just about few invoke of ndctl cmd. @Jay, are you ok merge this back to the main spec?'}, {'account_id': 11347, 'date': '2019-05-20 08:46:38.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-20 18:37:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(8 comments)

I'm still -1 on keeping these specs separate. The discussion here of how to name and map namespaces is inextricable from the discussion of same in the other spec.

Unless some other core feels quite strongly about this, I would like to see the specs combined.

More -1 for lack of clarity on the mechanism of mapping the resource class names to the namespaces. TL;DR:

- If we can rely on ndctl -n being available, the conf option should simply be a whitelist of those labels.
- If not, the conf option should be a list of $rc_name:$byte_capacity tuples so that the $byte_capacity can be used to match which $rc_name corresponds to which namespace.

The former would be much nicer IMO; otherwise you have to differentiate namespaces of the same size somehow."}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2019-05-21 06:54:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 5754, 'date': '2019-05-21 07:39:48.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-05-21 19:50:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 11347, 'date': '2019-05-23 08:45:22.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 6:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 11347, 'date': '2019-05-27 05:56:21.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Merged this spec to the main spec.'}]
